Witte, having received copies of the letters from Heyse, wrote an account of them, with copious (translated) ex- tracts, in an article entitled Neu aufyefundene Briesc des Dante Alliqhieri,² which appeared in Bla'tter fiir literarische Unterhaltuny in May, 1838, and prepared to edit and publish them. But while he was engaged upon the work his portfolio containing the transcript of the letters was stolen from him, and it was more than two years before he could succeed in getting fresh copies made.3 In the meantime, attention having been directed to the Ms. by the publication of Witte’s article, one of the employes at the Vatican Library, Massi by name, took copies of the letters on his own account with the intention of fore- stalling Witte's projected edition.
